Document Sources.Sourced Statement: According to U.S. Census data, just over half of those renters spend 90% of their income or more on rent.
The city’s current range of allowable annual rent increases — anywhere from 3% to 8% depending on inflation — is higher than the increases permitted in most other California cities with rent control.
The consumer price index in L.A. rose 21%.
Rents in rent-controlled L.A. apartments were allowed to rise 36%.
About 59% of the city’s renters spend more than 30% of their income on rent, a level considered unaffordable by federal government standards.
LAist obtained the report through a public records request.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “What [the report] is trying to do is make a PR effort to lay the groundwork to chip away at what little ability landlords have in L.A. to be able to raise rents and be able to keep up with their costs,” Yukelson said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles representative
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: LAist shared the report with advocates for landlords and tenants.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Small landlords are able to maintain their profits and draw income above their expenses — they haven't been overly burdened by rent stabilization,” said Christina Boyar, a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Tenant advocates took a very different view of the report.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The report shows that rent costs exceeding what tenants can pay is a primary cause of homelessness,” Boyar said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Tenant advocates took a very different view of the report.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I think when it's a politically contentious issue, there are attempts to manage the conversation,” Flaming said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Daniel Flaming, president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report, said he didn’t have a good answer for why the report was kept under wraps.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The substance of the report is final. It was submitted as a final report and accepted by the city as a final work product.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Daniel Flaming, president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report, said he didn’t have a good answer for why the report was kept under wraps.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The Los Angeles ceiling and floor are atypically high for rent-controlled cities,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: On balance, Flaming said the report shows that L.A.’s policies diverge significantly from how other California cities handle rent control.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Among cities that have elected to control rents — and not all cities have — Los Angeles appears to be tilted toward landlords.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: On balance, Flaming said the report shows that L.A.’s policies diverge significantly from how other California cities handle rent control.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “As we await the finalized version of this report, it’s heartening to see so much data supporting the policy changes that renters have been demanding — especially when it comes to preventing excessive rent increases that can devastate working families.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: In an email reacting to the Economic Roundtable report, Soto-Martínez told LAist,

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: LAist shared the report with advocates for landlords and tenants.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: LAist shared the report with advocates for landlords and tenants.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Sharon Sandow, a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department, told LAist last week the document was still a “draft report,” and they didn't have a specific date lined up for its release.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Sharon Sandow, a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department, told LAist last week
